title: Wednesday, 24th May, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
BE11:01am

Off we go then!

BE11:03am

And I must say, it's pretty awesome how the AV editorial system logs me off automatically at 11.01am each day!

BE11:03am

Anyway.

11:03 am
BE11:03am

Have a picture.

BE11:03am

BE11:04am

Yeah! That's a picture. We usually go with a guy in suit.

11:04 am
BE11:04am

It's Perugino's Resurrection panel from San Francesco al Prato, of course.

BE11:04am

What we have is Jesus levitating above his tomb. And oddly, he's holding a St George's Cross.

BE11:04am

(Except, needless to say, it's not a St George's Cross as we'd understand it now.)

11:04 am
BE11:04am

(It's possibly the flag of Genoa, though why that'd be on a painting from a church a few hundred miles south in Perugia isn't obvious.)

BE11:05am

(Or maybe there's a line to trace here through the early stages of the schism to explain its inclusion.)

BE11:05am

(Or it might be that Perugino just thought red on white looked nice. Dunno. I'm not an art historian.)

11:05 am
BE11:05am

Anyhoo ... you can see it in the background here.

BE11:05am

undefined
11:06 am
BE11:06am

And so to M&A.

Glencore PLC (GLEN:LSE): Last: 290.40, down 1.55 (-0.53%), High: 290.90, Low: 285.70, Volume: 14.65m
BE11:06am

WSJ hit publish on the story we were all making calls on in recent weeks.

11:07 am
BE11:07am

In fact, they hit publish while the market report I'd filed mentioning the rumour was still in the queue to be put online. Which is a wee bit of an irritation.

BE11:08am

The story being that Glencore's approached Bunge (informally, whatever that means) and Bunge's told them to get stuffed.

BE11:08am

Bunge saying this morning that talks are not active.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

Here's the FT story, several days in the making: https://www.ft.com...-82b6-896b95f30f58

BE11:10am

And some sellside to explain why it was all totally predictable.

BE11:10am

(I don't remember a lot of sellside predicting it, needless to say, but that might just be my memory failing.)

11:10 am
BE11:10am

Here's Barclays.

BE11:10am

This move is not hugely surprising: Glencore management had purposefully set up the structure of GAL to be a consolidator in the agricultural space given obtaining scale, particularly in the US, was only realistically possible via acquisitions. Glencore has previously noted they see GAL as an independent 'Xstrata-type entity' with its own balance sheet, management and growth strategy.

BE11:11am

While we are unclear on transaction structure at this stage, the implication of the statement is a merger. GAL is privately owned with shareholders Glencore (50%), CPPIB (40%) and BCIM (10%). Therefore the ability of GAL as a private entity to acquire a public entity with equity is limited. So the deal would need to be funded by cash (if structured as GAL acquiring Bunge) vs. equity and/or cash (if Bunge acquiring GAL).

11:10 am
BE11:11am

Looking at valuations, the most recent valuation marker for GAL is Canada Pension Plan (CPPIB) and British Columbia Investment Management’s (BCIM) investments in 50% of GAL in April 2016 and June 2016 respectively, which implied an equity value of $6.25bn and EV of $9.6bn (100% basis). We forecast EBITDA of $803m in 2017 and $805m in 2018 implying EV/EBITDA multiples of 12x and 11.9x. As an alternative the multiples of peers ADM, Bunge, Baywa-Bayerische and Andersons Inc in 2017-18 of 9x and 8.1x respectively, imply an average EV of $6.9bn for GAL. Meanwhile Bunge has an undisturbed market cap of $9.84bn (pre share price rally of 16.6% today) and net debt of $4.37bn vs. EBITDA of $1,832m and $2,008m (2017-18 respectively, using Bloomberg consensus).

BE11:11am

And JP Morgan from the target perspective.

BE11:11am

BG’s stock closed at $81.70, ~1.4x price/book (and ~8.3x EV/EBITDA) on our 2017 estimates. We note that the stock has traded YTD as high as $82.07 (before reporting weaker than expected Q1 results earlier this month). Overall, the approach in itself is not that surprising following a Q1 earnings call in which BG’s CEO was candid about the case for industry consolidation “becoming more obvious”, particularly in grain handling and global distribution. BG’s relatively dismissive tone was perhaps more surprising, in our view, although the details of any earlier discussions (and implied valuation) are unknown. Sugarcane fundamentals in Brazil have deteriorated in recent months, likely limiting BG’s near term strategic options for its sugarcane assets. Absent the potential re-rating of the stock on a divestment of those assets, BG’s core businesses remain under pressure, with Agribusiness margins weighed down by burdensome supplies of crops in all producer regions and a recovery in its Food & Ingredients business seemingly restrained by the broad economic weakness and lack of consumer confidence in Brazil.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

Goldman also.

BE11:11am

Strategically, an acquisition of Bunge would provide Glencore with a strong footing in the US agricultural market (Bunge is among the biggest grain trading companies; active in the flow of crops from farmer’s fields to food plants and livestock operations). A deal would also mark a return to M&A by Glencore, having divested many assets (including a 49.9% sale of its Agricultural business in 2016) previously. Despite having a relatively sound balance sheet, and against a backdrop of relatively stable commodity prices, Glencore has continued to divest assets this year. We highlight that Glencore owns c.50.1% of the Glencore Agriculture Ltd.
We value Glencore (last close: 292.9p) using a SOTP: (1) Industrial assets are valued at 4.5x 2018E EV/EBITDA; (2) the marketing division is valued at 15x 2018E P/E; and (3) the listed entities are marked to market. This leads to a 12-month price target of 360p. Commodity risks, streaming agreements and FX moves are key risks to our view.

BE11:12am

And Merrill.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

Wait, no, not Merrill.

BE11:12am

Jason Fairclough has used the "Bunge jumping" pun as a headline.

BE11:12am

I can't be party to that kind of thing.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

Instead, here are a few flashes from Glazenberg at the AGM.

BE11:13am

*GLENCORE CEO SAYS WILL SEEK TO BUY RIVAL COMPANIES IN FUTURE

BE11:14am

*GLENCORE CEO SAYS WILL SEEK TO ADD COPPER ASSETS IN FUTURE

11:14 am
BE11:15am

And I meant Glasenberg, of course. Not sure why I added the Yankee Z.

undefined
BE11:18am

(@Blue horseshoe: we've mentioned Gemalto again, again, again and again on here and our enquiries as to whether rumours are accurate have had no encouragement whatsoever. We've no desire to keep mentioning it, as under the circumstances it begins to feel very like a ramp.)

11:19 am
BE11:19am

(@Groundhog: you're right, under Panel rules Glencore didn't have to make a statement. But I'd be cautious to read too much into that.)

BE11:19am

So, what else?

BE11:20am

Results, I guess. There are lots of them.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

Berendsen requested. We can go there briefly.

BE11:21am

Elis told to go away.

BE11:21am

2017 guidance reiterated, 2018 AstraZeneca'd.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

As in, set at implausible levels based on a business that doesn't yet exist in any meaningful way.

BE11:22am

Might work! Worked for AstraZeneca, in a roundabout way.

BE11:23am

The question remains whether investors want to believe a jam-tomorrow story or take the French cash and paper.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

If it's the former, they're braver than I'd be.

BE11:24am

Here's Barclays.

BE11:24am

BERENDSEN (UW, TP 700p) – Berendsen has released a statement reiterating the Board’s belief that last week’s proposal from Elis (ELIS.PA, N/R) significantly undervalues Berendsen. Today’s statement provides a little more detail than last Thursday’s statement on the reasons for this belief, of which perhaps the most interesting is a 2018 operating profit forecast of £170m (alongside the reiteration of the 2017 operating profit forecast of £150m) – this is 10% higher than current Thomson Reuters consensus of £154.5m (range £149-160m). It is not clear at this stage how the £20m profit bridge from FY17 to FY18 is constructed given capex investment will likely take a number of years to deliver targeted returns and we struggle to see organic growth experiencing a meaningful acceleration. The statement also reiterates the view that the approach is opportunistic given the relative performance of Berendsen vs Elis shares in recent months compared to longer term trends – given our negative view of BRSN’s strategy to significantly accelerate growth capex in a modest growth market, we are not convinced of the relevance of BRSN’s share price 12mths ago as the strategy has fundamentally altered over the past few months. We do not disagree with the comment from Berendsen that there are risks from combining the two businesses but also believe consolidation in European workwear (particularly Benelux and Germany) is key to improving returns given the importance of route density – we also note the largest regions for each of Elis (France) and Berendsen (UK/Nordics) have no overlap so would not experience integration risk. The statement also notes the higher leverage that the combined entity would have (3.4x proforma vs BRSN at 1.2x at 31/12/16) – while leverage would be higher we note that (i) Elis has operated with leverage at significantly higher levels having been in private equity ownership prior to its IPO in 2015 and (ii) given the cash and cost synergies forecast by Elis in their proposal document last week, leverage would seem unlikely to remain at these elevated levels. BRSN trades on a CY2017 PE of 19.0x, falling to 18.2x in CY2018.

11:25 am
undefined
BE11:27am

(@Boncoeur: we have very different definitions of "heavy selloff")

BE11:27am

Oh, and since we mentioned Brown-Forman yesterday on here we should note the reports overnight.

11:27 am
BE11:28am

Approach from Constellation Brands rejected, says CNBC among others.

BE11:28am

Which goes some way to explain the very sharp rally in decent days.

BE11:29am

Note, the Brown family has 61% voting control of the company

11:29 am
BE11:29am

And have long said independence is the preferred path.

BE11:29am

You've also got Constellation levered up to the extreme on 3.7x.

BE11:30am

Here's Suntrust.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Our estimate is that the initial proposal was made weeks ago and then leaked following BF.B’s rejection. We believe this is the reason behind BF.B’s shares' 20% increase over the last month (vs. S&P +0.5%).

BE11:02am

Good morning, welcome to Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily whatever this is.

BE11:31am

We Question the Fit for STZ: Overall, there are no real synergies with STZ’s beer business (58% of total sales) in terms of geographic expansion as STZ only owns the rights to sell the beer portfolio in the US. Additionally, BF.B is a lower growth company with 3%-4% organic growth estimated for this year compared to STZ’s ~8%. However, we do believe STZ will continue to look for ways to expand in the brown spirits category. We note that STZ recently acquired High West Distillery and made a minority investment in Catoctin Creek Distilling (Roundstone Rye, Rabble Rouser, and Watershed Gin), both of which are supplied by MGPI (MGPI, $54.15, Buy).

11:31 am
BE11:31am

(@Scalper: we've heard those names too. There are only so many.)

BE11:31am

Now, I've nothing to add to that analysis right now.

BE11:32am

But there remains a lot of noise around.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

Might all be stale bulls trying to save their skin. Might not. Dunno.

undefined
BE11:32am

Comments busy today. That's nice to see.

11:33 am
BE11:33am

Given the choice I'd be out in the sun right now, but you folks have a different mettle. So, BAE mentioned.

BAE Systems PLC (BA.:LSE): Last: 659.50, up 18 (+2.81%), High: 660.00, Low: 642.50, Volume: 3.29m
BE11:35am

All on the US budget, which has been confirmed as the strain of populism that starves hardship support programmes and buys missiles instead.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

UBS has the summary reading.

BE11:36am

BAE has c.37% of its group sales exposed to US defence. The FY18 base Modernization budget request came in 9% above FY17 levels (6% higher including OCO) and 4% above UBSe. This supports our view on the organic revenue and profit growth potential for BAE's US businesses. For 2019/2020e we forecast 6%/7% organic revenue growth in Electronics and US Platforms – as typically there is an 18-24 month delay between enacted budget and industry revenue. We re-iterate our Buy rating with a price target of 730p.

BE11:37am

Modernization FY18 request includes a 12% growth for Air Force and 5% growth for Army while Navy modernization funding is broadly aligned with FY17. We believe this is supportive especially for BAE's F35 and Army exposure.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

However ..........

BE11:39am

.... if you're in a defence stock and aren't checking in with Sandy Morris of Jefferies, you're making a mistake.

BE11:39am

He's nonplussed.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

The FY18 US Defense Budget appears to be a “Placeholder” ahead of the main event of the FY19 Budget. Details of the latter – incorporating the new National Defense Strategy – may not be issued before February 2018. Assuming the FY19 budget does not become embroiled in a wider process of repealing or alleviating the 2011 Budget Control Act (the FY18 Base Budget request is US$52bn above DoD’s share of the FY18 Defense budget cap under current law) or in any other budget controversy, the higher budget authority would become available in October 2018 (later if there is a Continuing Resolution). There is always a lag before defence outlays – the cash spend – increases. We venture it could be 2H calendar 2019 before a defence contractor like BAE sees an increase in revenues.

BE11:40am

The usual thousands of pages of supporting information for the Defense Budget are – as we write - not available. We are also finding it challenging to fathom out what comparatives for FY17 the published FY18 documentation refers to (it seems to vary). Regardless, the FY18 Base Budget request is US$574.5bn versus an original FY17 request of US$521.8bn. That ostensibly looks positive, but the FY18 Base Budget was originally planned to be US$556.4bn, so the FY18 increase is 3.25%, in our view. That increase must absorb increased personnel numbers as well as greater than planned increases in pay for both military and civilian personnel. To be fair, the FY18 Budget commentary makes it clear that it is all about rebuilding warfighting readiness. In short, the increases in Procurement (and the FY17 comparatives have not been adjusted to reflect the additional funding request made in March 2017) across each Service are indeed modest relative to those for Operations and Maintenance.

BE11:41am

He's no more enthusiastic than "hold" on BAE. Overall thesis is that the US returning to growth but the pace is likely to disappoint.

11:41 am
undefined
BE11:42am

Still going through comments on the right. We'll reach results sometime, maybe.

BE11:43am

Acacia first though.

11:43 am
BE11:44am

Had you been up at 7am you could have watched President Dr. John Magufuli deliver his findings to the Presidential Committee on the ore export ban.

BE11:44am

They livestreamed it: http://ikulu.go.tz/index.php/

BE11:45am

The upshot being that Tanzania is accusing Acacia of under-reporting the mineral content of its exports.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

So, the ban still stands.

BE11:46am

But then, this happened.

BE11:46am

DAR ES SALAAM (Reuters) - Tanzania's president fired the mining minister and the chief of the state-run mineral audit agency on Wednesday, after receiving a report into whether mining companies were under-declaring the value of their exports.

President John Magufuli's decision, announced in a speech, signals an escalation of tensions between the government and the industry, which has denied engaging in tax evasion. Mining accounts for about 4 percent of Tanzania's gross domestic product.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

http://af.reuters....dAFKBN18K13I-OZATP

BE11:47am

So .................. who knows! What we can say is that Acacia denies the accusation, that it was under-declaring gold in containers by a factor greater than 10 times.

BE11:49am

As I understand it, there's still a second committee to report.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

Wait, Caz has an explainer.

BE11:50am

The second Presidential Committee is assessing the wider-reaching economic and regulatory issues relating to the export of metallic mineral concentrates from Tanzania. There is no official timeline for this release but based on the timing of the first committee, presentation of findings sometime in H1 still remains credible.

BE11:50am

And as a reminder ............

11:50 am
BE11:50am

ACA is also impacted by the regulation requiring the sell-down of a 30% stake in each mining license to local shareholders by Aug’17 (announced at the Q1). If enforced, we estimate $640-720m NPV would have to be “sold” to local entities. If there is a favourable ruling on the concentrate export ban, we expect ACA may seek a definitive agreement with the government to include a waiver on the local shareholding requirement.

undefined
BE11:52am

(@Soundbuy: that study was based on such poor scientific practice it made my teeth itch.)

11:52 am
BE11:52am

WPP mentioned.

WPP PLC (WPP:LSE): Last: 1,687, up 14 (+0.84%), High: 1,690, Low: 1,669, Volume: 1.05m
BE11:52am

Yep, weak yesterday.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

Was struggling to find a reason by press time yesterday. But I didn't speak to Liberum, who had Sorrell in for the afternoon.

BE11:54am

He was positive about WPP, of course, but not so positive for ads in general.

BE11:54am

Here's Liberum's short summary.

11:54 am
BE11:54am

The overall message was one of confidence on the supposed structural risks facing the Agencies, WPP’s position and margin expansion. If there was a “fly in the ointment”, it was that the global advertising market is not performing as expected given the general economic picture. However, these risks are more than priced in and WPP’s strengths make it our preferred Agency, a sub-sector where we think the secular risks have been overdone. Reiterate Buy.

BE11:54am

WPP stated it saw itself as having four key competitive advantages over its peers. In order of magnitude, these were (1) a fully integrated offering; (2) its strong position in faster growing markets, which is c. 1/3 of the business; (3) its capacities in digital, which make up c. 40% of the business and (4) its data capabilities, via Kantar, with Quantitative-exposed revenues making up c. 25% of the business and where its capabilities are unique amongst the major Agency groups. On (3), Sir Martin emphasised how the Kantar offering was attractive to clients and that its based on a “opt-in” mechanism (i.e. clients have to ask to sign up) showed that concerns over Kantar’s proprietary model were overdone. On (4), it was pointed out that the new European data protection rules (GDPR) should benefit “first party” owners of data such as WPP’s Kantar business.

BE11:55am

And a bit more on the negative stuff.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

The one “fly in the ointment” from the presentation was that Sir Martin could not explain why advertising had not picked up despite what seems to be a more favourable economic environment and anecdotal evidence suggesting that there was a pick-up in global capex (advertising is, in effect, intangible capex i.e. investment). Our US CEO Business Roundtable survey, which has proven to be an accurate 3-6 month lead indicator of Agency organic revenue growth in the past is pointing to a pick-up in 2H, which would be in line with the general comments from the Agencies so it will be interesting to see whether this is delivered, given the reliance on 2H growth of several groups.

undefined
BE11:56am

Do you think we can go all session without mentioning a single results update?

11:56 am
BE11:56am

That'd be an achievement of sorts when M&S, Kingfisher and Dixons are all on the tape.

BE11:57am

It'd be remiss, however, not to mention a downgrade of TalkTalk.

Talktalk Telecom Group PLC (TALK:LSE): Last: 176.50, down 6.4 (-3.50%), High: 180.50, Low: 174.60, Volume: 2.82m
11:57 am
BE11:57am

Goldman. They prefer Liberty.

BE11:58am

The UK fixed market has enjoyed strong price inflation in recent years and whilst operators have largely raised ‘headline’ pricing in 2017 to date, signs of increased discounting and TALK aiming to become more of a ‘challenger’ are raising questions about the structural attractiveness of the market. In addition, recent regulatory decisions could have the effect of reducing the scope for price increases (Narrowband and WLA (Wholesale Local Access) reviews). Lastly, the regulator is targeting increased ‘full fibre’ rollouts, which we see as having the potential to reshape the competitive landscape over the next 5-10 years.

BE11:59am

So, broadband penetration now c.90% and pay TV is 65%. Growth story played out.

11:59 am
BE12:00pm

And faster lines are not terribly expensive.

BE12:00pm

BE12:01pm

Leaving TalkTalk nowhere really, in market terms.

12:01 pm
undefined
BE12:02pm

Wow, is it midday already? Time flies.

BE12:03pm

Still loads we haven't covered. Results, mostly, but also Softcat and Touchstone and ..... well, perhaps we can revisit tomorrow depending on demand.

12:03 pm
BE12:04pm

For now, I'm off outside. And I suggest you do the same.

BE12:04pm

Afternoon all.

BE11:30am

In our opinion, STZ does not have the financial resources to make a hostile bid for BF.B as it is currently 3.7x levered. More importantly, we believe BF.B and the Brown family, which owns 61% voting control of the company, would prefer to stay independent and focus solely on spirits (vs. imported beer and wine). We note that Brown-Forman company shares are split between Class A Voting (170 million shares; Brown family owns 61%) and Class B Non-Voting shares (215 million shares).
